Question: How many times has Kirk ripped his shirt in this series?
Narrative: Considering that there were only 79 episodes, it seems like a considerable number, doesn't it?

Question: What organization did Balok say he represented?
Narrative:
In this episode, the commander of the "Fesarius" was found to be a child-like alien who loved
 the beverage know as "Tranya".

Description: Where No Man Has Gone Before
Question:
In this episode, two crew were endowed with God-like powers. Which
two crew?
Narrative:
The two crew were endowed with God-like powers due to a force field that the Enterprise passed
through. Mitchell became power-mad, while Dehner was able to control her response.

Question:
Crewman Kevin Riley barricaded himself in Engineering and repatedly
sang the song "I'll Take You Home Again Kathleen". Which of these
singers also performed this song?
Narrative: This song was included on Elvis Presley's album "Fool".

Description: City on the Edge of Forever
Question:
What drug did Doctor McCoy accidentally inject himself with in
this episode
Narrative:
This drug, when given in large amount s, can cause serious mental instability. In this case, it caused McCoy to go
temporarily insane which ultimately made him jump through the "Guardian of Forever" into Earth's past.

Question: In this episode, what happened to Commodore Decker's crew?
Answer 1:
They transported to the surface
 of a planet
Answer 2:
They abondoned ship in
escape pods
Correct Answer:
They transported to the surface
 of a planet
Narrative:
They crew transported to the surface of the planet that Decker's ship was orbiting. Ultimately, the Doomsday
Machine destroyed the planet, resulting in the death of Decker's entire crew.

Question:
In this episode, two aliens took human form and had magical powers.
What device gave them this ability?
Narrative:
This device was used by "Sylvia" to transform herself into a cat, and into a woman. Sylvia and Korob were actually creatures
that could not survive the conditions on the planet without the Transmuter, and they ultimately died when Kirk destroyed it.

Question:
In this episode, Kirk teaches his captors a fictional card game. What
was the name of this game?
Narrative:
In this ridiculous game, some of the rules are: The second card is turned up, except on Tuesdays, If the player gets 2 Jacks, they get
another card "if it's dark outside", and the best cards to get are a King and Queen, except at night, when you want a Queen and
a Jack.

Question:
In this episode, what was the name of the alien species the crew of
the Enterprise encountered?
Narrative:
The "Melkots", as a result of the Enterprise crew ignoring a warning not to approach their planet, caused the landing party to
participate in a deadly "Shootout at the O.K. Corral" simulation.

Question:
In this episode, the crew encounters children who, when they reach
adulthood turn into what the children call what?
Narrative:
Obviously a warped version of "grown-ups". The inhabitants of an almost identical Earth planet attempted to create immortality,
and instead killed all of the adults, but kept the children young for hundreds of years. In the end, once they did reach adulthood,
they also died quickly.

Question:
In this episode, Kirk finds someone from his Starfleet Acadamy days,
and has a prolonged fight with him. Who is this person?
Narrative: An "upper-classman", Finnegan tormented Kirk in his acadamy days. In this episode, Kirk gets a chance to "get even".

Question:
In this episode, Kirk and his landing party encounter an alien
entity who claims to have studied Earth's past. Who is this alien?
Narrative:
Although Trelane appears to be a powerful alien, with powers that are almost magical, he is later found to be an immature
member of a powerful species, and treats his "pets" and "toys" poorly.

Question:
In this episode, "Nomad" has incorrectly idenfied Kirk as its creator.
Kirk has to destroy Nomad before it destroys the Enterprise. How does
Kirk accomplish this?
Answer 2:
Tricks Nomad into "beaming"
into a star
Answer 4:
Generated a strong
magnetic field into Nomad.
Narrative:
Because Nomad has mistakenly identified Kirk as "The Kirk", his creator, and Nomad values "perfection", Kirk is able to
cause Nomad to destroy itself as a result of its "imperfection".

Question:
Dr. Richard Daystrom introduced M5, a new computer on the
Enterprise. What type of computer was this?
Narrative:
Multitronic computers become the future of computing in Star Trek. They were a significant improvement from the
previous Duotronic computer systems. Of course, this doesn't occur until well after the self-preservation and destroying of
other Starfleet vessel issues were ironed out.

Question: How many times does Doctor McCoy claim, "I'm a Doctor, not a...."?
Narrative:
11 times in 79 episodes. That's pretty significant. He has claimed not to be a bricklayer, an escalator and an engineer, 
among other things.

Question:
What was another name for the Pon Farr, that caused Vulcans to
mate or die?
Narrative: In Amok Time, Spock must mate or die. That sucks.

Question: What did the "Doomsday Machine" use to destroy planets?
Narrative: Commodore Decker described the beam fired from the Doomsday Machine as antiprotons - "Absolutely pure".

Question: In which star system is the planet Vulcan located?
Narrative: This is actually a real star system, located approximately 16.5 light years from earth.

Question: General order 7 prohibits travel to which planet?
Narrative:
Due to the Talosians ability to telepathically induce hallucinations and make people believe what is not true, Starfleet
instituted General Order 7, prohibiting travel to that planet "for any reason".

Question: Who played Spock's father and also a Romulan Commander?
Narrative:
Although all of these actors have played multiple roles in Star Trek: The Original Series, Lenard was Spock's father and also portrayed
the Romulan Commander in the episode Balance of Terror.

Question: Who inhabits the planet Holberg 917G?
Narrative: Flint was an immortal human who claimed to also be Mozart, and a number of other significant people in Earth's history.

Question: What species language is problematic for the universal translator?
Narrative: The universal translator had difficulty with the Tholians language, perhaps due to their unique structure.

Question: What studio originally produced this series?
Narrative: Desilu was owned by Lucille Ball, along with her husband, Desi Arnez.

Question:
Although never used, this series opening music had lyrics. Who wrote
these lyrics?
Narrative:
The lyrics were never intended to be sung. Reportedly, Roddenberry only wanted them so he could pocket some profit from them
as a co-writer credit.

Question: What does dilithium do in propulsion systems?
Answer 1:
Stabilize and focus matter and
antimatter
Answer 2:
Provides fuel for the warp
drive
Correct Answer:
Stabilize and focus matter and
antimatter
Narrative:
Dilithium acts as a stabilizer for the warp engines by focusing the matter/antimatter reaction to contain the massive energy
output necessary for warp propulsion.

Question:
When Wil Wheaton asked for a raise, what did the studio offer him
instead of a monetary raise?
Narrative: Wheaton allegedly told the producers  "So what should I tell my landlord when I can't pay my rent? 'Don't worry, I just made Lieutenant'?!

Question:
After the second season, production planned to remove Geordi's VISOR
due to surgery to restore his natural eyesight. Why didn't this occur?
Answer 3:
It made him a positive role-model
for the disabled community
Correct Answer:
It made him a positive role-model
for the disabled community
Narrative: Recognizing that the character had become a positive role model for the disabled community, producers dropped the plan.

Question:
Gene Roddenberry initially refused to cast Patrick Stewart as Captain
Picard for a number of reasons.  Who campaigned for Stewart leading
to the acceptance of his casting?
Narrative: Roddenberry wanted a character who was younger, with a full head of hair.

Question: What was "The Picard Maneuver"?
Narrative: The original uniforms were apparently so uncomfortable that Patrick Stewart often pulled his uniform tunic down with a snap.

Question:
The Borg became the main adversary in this series. What species was
originally intended to fulfil this role?
Narrative:
Although they ended up as more of a comic relief, the Ferengi were originally intended to be the main adversarial species in this
series.

Question: Which character in this episode is Patrick Stewart's real-life son?
Narrative: Patrick Stewart's real-life son, Daniel Stewart. In the episode, he was named after Kamin's friend, Batai.

Question:
In this episode, Picard portrays a private detective in a holodeck
simulation. What character does Picard play?
Narrative:
Dixon Hill embodies the quintessential characteristics of a hard-boiled detective from 1940s noir fiction. He is tough, street-smart, and 
operates in a gritty, urban setting.

Question:
What caused the demise of the people of the planet Minos in this
episode?
Answer 2:
Their own weapons turned
on them
Correct Answer:
Their own weapons turned
on them
Narrative:
The Minosians created a weapon that was able to learn and adapt, which ultimately turned on their creators, destroying the entire
civilization as a result.

Question:
In this episode, how does the landing party eventually end their
entrapment?
Answer 1:
They buy the casino/hotel, thus
ending the story
Answer 2:
They found a way to
disrupt the program
Answer 3:
The formed an alliance with the
characters
Correct Answer:
They buy the casino/hotel, thus
ending the story
Narrative:
In this episode, the landing party enters a simulation of a hotel/casino through a revolving door. Once inside, they were trapped
until they determined that following the storyline of the book the simulation was based on would conclude the program, thus freeing them.

Question:
In this episode, what did Ambassador K'Ehleyr and Worf mainly have
in common?
Answer 3: They are married to each other
Narrative: Although they both have strong personalities and they are both Klingon, the main commonality between these two is their son, Alexander.

Question: In this episode, what is significant about Q?
Narrative:
In addition to having lost his powers, Q is also completely human, including being mortal. This is particularly distressing to Q, as some
species that he has tormented in the past have learned of this, and seek revenge.

Question:
Jeffrey Combs has played multiple roles in the Star Trek franchise, but
never appeared in this series. Which of these actors has?
Narrative:
Tim Russ portrayed Devor in "Starship Mine". He also appeared on the bridge of Enterprise-B in "Tapestry" as a background character. Of
course he is best known as Tuvok on Voyager.

Question: In this episode, what ancient weapon were Picard and Vash looking for?
Narrative: This weapon was supposed to have the ability to halt nuclear fusion in a star. Imagine what that would do to a civilization.

Question:
In this episode, Picard is shown to have needed an artifical heart as a
result of being impaled by an alien during a game of Dom-Jot? What
alien species did this?
Narrative:
Picard and his friends discovered that the Nausicaans had rigged the table to cheat. Picard, known for his bold and sometimes brash nature
 in his youth, confronted the Nausicaans and got into a fight with them.

Question:
In this episode, what species is mentioned to have influenced the 
Ventaxians?
Narrative:
There is a great deal of Klingon influence in this story. It is mentioned that first contact with Ventax II was made by the Klingons 70 years
 previously. Data mentions a legal case involving a Klingon, and Ardra uses a Klingon image to intimidate the Ventaxians.

Question:
What species, to later appear in Deep Space Nine, was the symbiot
in this episode?
Narrative: The Trill species will return in the characters of Ezri and Jadzia Dax and others in later series.

Question: In which episode of this series did Thomas Riker first appear?
Answer 1: The Best of Both Worlds, Part I
Narrative: Thomas Riker, created as a duplicate of William Riker as a result of a transporter accident first appeared in this episode.

Question:
In the episode "New Ground", what method of propulsion was 
introduced?
Narrative:
The soliton wave generator on a planet would create a powerful, stable wave in subspace. This wave would then be used to propel a starship at 
faster-than-light speeds without the need for a warp drive on the ship itself. Ultimately, it failed.

Question: In this episode, Worf and Alexander play what role in the simulation?
Narrative:
Alexander, being a fan of Westerns, eagerly immerses himself in the role of the sheriff's deputy, while Worf reluctantly takes on the role
 of the sheriff.

Question: In the episode "Relics", what TOS character was featured?
Narrative:
The Enterprise stumbles upon a Dyson sphere, with a ship crashed on the outer surface. An away team finds some systems still powered up
 and the chief engineer from the old Enterprise, Montgomery Scott, locked in the transporter cycle.

Question: In this episode, what primary role does Data play in the simulation?
Narrative:
Data appears in the simulation in multiple rolls, including a prisoner named Eli Hollander, who is Frank's son. Funny note, as the simulation
progresses, Data himself starts speaking with a southern drawl.

Description: Chain of Command, Parts I and II
Question:
In this episode, Picard is captured by the Cardassians and is tortured by
his interrogator, Gul Madred. Madred asks Picard how many lights he
sees. What is Picard's reply.
Narrative:
There are actually four lights, but Madred insists there are five, and wants Picard to break by answering that there are five lights. Picard never
gives in, no matter how long this torture persists.

Question:
Unlike Kirk in TOS, Picard is not often thought of as a "ladies man". But
he did have several love interests over the course of the series. Of the
following pairs, which were love interests of Picard?
Answer 3:
Dr. Leah Brahms and  Commander
Shelby
Narrative:
Vash and Daren were both love interests of Captain Picard over the course of the series. Although Daren only appeared in a single episode,
Vash made several appearances.

Question:
In this episode, Data discovers his "Mother" on the planet Atrea IV. What
was her name?
Narrative:
It turns out that Dr. Tainer is also an android, but believes she is human. She was constructed by Dr. Noonien Soong, who was also responsible
 for creating Data and Lore. She was constructed to believe she was human and was given the memories and personality of Soong's real 
wife, Juliana O'Donnell.

Question: How many characters did Brent Spiner portray in this episode?
Narrative:
Spiner portrayed five characters in all, including Data. Investigating a rogue comet that's been traveling throughout the universe for over
 87 million years, Picard discovers alien beings within the comet, which infest the computer systems on the Enterprise, as well as Data.

Question:
Walter Koenig did not appear in this series. But he is credited with writing
an episode. Which episode did he write?
Narrative:
Koenig wrote this episode, becoming the first Star Trek actor to write an episode. He was not hired to portray Chekov due to
budget limitations.

Question:
The landing party encounters slug-like creatures that Spock believes
have what ability?
Narrative: Spock believes that these slug-like creatures have telepathic abilities, but process their thoughts at a speed too fast to comprehend.

Question: In this series, as a child, what did Spock have as a pet?
Narrative: As a child, Spock had a pet Sehlat named I-Chaya. In the episode "The Infinite Vulcan", Unfortunately, I-Chaya died in this episode.

Question: What cat-like creature was introduced in this episode?
Narrative:
The Kzinti are known for their aggressive and warlike nature. They have a hierarchical society with a strong emphasis on military
 prowess and conquest.

Question: What artifact were the crew of the Enterprise seeking in this episode?
Narrative:
The artifact was a highly sacred and revered relic for the Skorr, a bird-like warrior species. It is a symbol of great religious and cultural 
significance to the Skorr, embodying their spiritual essence and unity.

Question:
In this episode, a holodeck was depicted. The first time in the franchise.
What other name was this known by?
Narrative:
Some consider this as the prototype of the Holodeck used in Star Trek: The Next Generation, Star Trek: Deep Space Nine, and
 Star Trek: Voyager. In Deep Space Nine, it was known as a Holosuite, which Quark owned. It was housed in Quark's bar.

Question:
Bem was an unusual alien with certain physical traits? Which of the
following traits did Bem posses?
Answer 1:
He had a segmented body and
each segment was detachable
Correct Answer:
He had a segmented body and
each segment was detachable
Narrative: Bem was a member of the Pandorian species.

Question: What alien species was featured as "prey" in this episode?
Narrative:
Tosk was a prey species from birth, and was revered on his home planet for not being captured. When the hunters caught up to him on
the space station, he was humilated. But O'Brien helped him to escape, thus saving Tosk's reputation.

Question:
When the Wadi caught Quark cheating at the game they introduced, they
forced several crew members into a simulation of the game. What was
this game called?
Narrative:
The Wadi was the first species to make first contact from the Gamma quadrant, and a good impression would be a good start. Unfortunaty,
they kept winning at the game they introduced in Quarks bar, and Quark saw no other solution than to cheat. Bad idea.

Question:
Chief O'Brien was drafted to be the Bajoran village's storyteller when the
village leader fell ill. He was tasked with saving the village from what
dreaded entity?
Narrative:
The village leader's apprentice was supposed to take over when needed, but the village leader didn't think he was prepared, so he
drafted O'Brien. Fortunately, this was just what was needed to get the apprentice sufficiently ready to address the problem.

Question:
In this episode, what is the name of the female Ferengi who falls for
Quark?
Narrative:
Pel, being a female Ferengi, wasn't allowed to accumulate profit, according to Ferengi law, so she disguised herself as a male. As luck
would have it, she fell in love with Quark, which caused quite a problem for all involved once she was discovered.

Question:
In this episode, Quark takes credit for the death of a drunk Klingon. The
Klingon's widow arrives on DS9 and forces him to marry her. What is
the name of the Klingon widow?
Narrative: In order for Grilka to save the House of Kozak, she needed to marry Quark.

Question:
In this episode, Jadzia falls in love with an inhabitant of the planet. The
planet periodically "phases", and disappears from normal space. Who
did she fall in love with?
Narrative:
Jadzia decides to stay with Deral on the planet when it phases. However, something goes wrong, and the planet can't phase, causing
the crew in the runabout to save Jadzia, allowing the planet to phase normally.

Question: Which of the following is true about runabouts, but not shuttlecraft?
Answer 1:
They have their own registry
number
Answer 2:
They are smaller than a
shuttlecraft
Answer 3:
They are not assigned to a starship
or space station
Answer 4:
They are less armed than
a shuttlecraft
Correct Answer:
They have their own registry
number
Narrative:
Runabouts are larger and have more defensive capabilities than a shuttlecraft. They are typically assigned to a starshp or space station, and
they have their own unique registry number. For example, the Rio Grande's registry was NCC 72452.

Question:
As a result of the Dominion threat, how many photon torpedos were
available on DS9?
Narrative:
It may seem like overkill, but the threat from the Dominion was real, and with the Cardassians added to their alliance, it doesn't seem like
5,000 photon torpedos was too many.

Question:
What was the purpose of Terok Nor prior to the Federation's occupation
of the space station?
Narrative:
Although it could be said that the station was a prison for Bajorans captured in the war between Cardassia and Bajor, its primary purpose was
an ore refinery.

Question:
In this episode we learn that the name of the Bajoran Wormhole is known
in Bajoran religious context as what?
Narrative:
The wormhole is one of few known "stable" wormholes, with one end in the Alpha quadrant, and the other in the Gamma quadrant. It is also the
home of the "Prophets", non-corporeal beings that are the source of the Bajoran religion.

Question:
What illegal technology does the Defiant have as a result of an agreement
between the Federation and the Romulans?
Narrative:
As a result of a treaty with the Romulans, the Federation agreed not to develop or implement cloaking technology. However, due to the Dominion
threat, an exception was made and the Defiant was fitted with a cloaking device.

Question:
In this first of two parts episode, an explosion occurs in what part of
the space station?
Narrative:
Odo immediately begins an investigation to determine the reason for this apparent attempt on Garak's life. However, Garak doesn't seem 
interested in cooperating. Odd, isn't it?

Question:
The Jem'Hadar are intentionally addicted to a drug created by the
Changelings to ensure loyalty. What is this drug called?
Narrative:
The Jem'Hadar are a warrior species created by the Changelings. They are loyal to the Changelings, but likely only because of the
Ketracel White, which has terrible consequences when not taken regularly.

Question:
Vorta are the administrators for the Changelings. When a replacement
is needed for a Vorta, how is it replaced?
Narrative:
Vorta believe they were  once small ape-like creatures that, as a result of saving a changeling from "solids" were given the gift of becoming
important humanoid status.

Question:
In this episode, Quark believes he is going to die. What does he do
as a result?
Answer 1: He decides to sell his remains
Answer 2:
He signs over ownership of
his bar to Rom
Answer 4:
He signs over ownership of
his bar to Morn
Correct Answer: He decides to sell his remains
Narrative: Obviously, Quark didn't die. But he might wish he did, considering the consequences of finding out he is not going to die after all.

Question:
In this episode, Sisko has visions of another life as an under-appreciated
writer in Earth's past. What magazine did he write for?
Narrative:
In this, one of the most well received episodes of the series, Sisko writes a story that is incredibly similar to his real life on DS9. But, in a time when
people of color are still discriminated against, he finds it impossible to get his story published.

Question:
In this episode, Sisko conspires to violate Federation regulations in order
to bring the Romulans into the Dominion war. Who does he conspire
with?
Narrative:
The Romulans believe that remaining neutral in the Dominion war is in their best interest. So Sisko conspires to convince the Romulans that
the Dominion intends on attacking them. This ploy certainly doesn't portray the Federation in the best light.

Question: What Bajoran discovered Odo and performed cruel experiments on him?
Narrative:
Dr. Mora, Odo's "father", discovered Odo as an infant, and performed many experiments, some cruiel and painful, to get the gelatinous form
to respond.

Question:
In this episode, Tuvok mind-melds with a crewman who has confessed to
murdering another crew. Who did Tuvok mind-meld with?
Narrative:
Suder, who murdered another crewman, allowed Tuvok to mind-meld with him in an attempt to calm his chaotic thoughts and urges. In the
process, Tuvok nearly loses himself to Suder's thoughts.

Question:
In this episode, Neelix pretends to be a Ferengi in an attempt to fool the
Ferengi who are defauding the inhabitants of a bronze age planet. Who
does Neelix claim to be?
Narrative:
Voyager comes across a pair of Alpha Quadrant Ferengis who have set themselves up as gods on a primitive planet. Voyager wants to end their reign and use the nearby
 wormhole to return home.

Question: In this episode, what relationship does Q want to have with Janeway?
Narrative: Civil war has erupted in the Q Continuum, and for some reason, Q believes that a Q child will restore balance. Seems fishy to  me.

Question:
In this episode, the holographic doctor creates a family for himself in the
holodeck. What about this family did Torres change to make it more
realistic?
Narrative:
The doctor's "son", became friends with a Klingon teenager who exhibited behaviors that the doctor did not want his
son to learn from him.

Question:
Voyager was an advanced starship that had several new features. Which
of these did Voyager have that were not typical of previous starships?
Narrative:
The packs had both mechanical and biological components, and contained bio-neural cells and neurodes which organized 
information more efficiently and faster than isolinear circuitry.

Question:
In this episode, what famous historical figure did Captain Janeway have
a conversation with?
Narrative:
Janeway turns to her Leonardo da Vinci holodeck program for inspiration and devises a risky plan to book safe passage through Borg
 space by working together with the Borg to defeat Species 8472.

Question:
What does Captain Janeway hope to get from the Borg by providing
technology to them that will defeat Species 8472?
Narrative:
The holographic doctor deviced nano-technology that would defeat Species 8472. Janeway offered an alliance with the Borg that would provide
the Borg with the technology "after" they were out of Borg space.

Question: Seven of Nine became part of Voyager's crew in what episode?
Narrative:
As a result of Species 8472 destroying her Borg Cube, Seven of Nine was transported along with the away team to Voyager, where
she became a permanent member of Voyager's crew.

Question:
Which Voyager crew were being portrayed by imposters in this
episode?
Narrative: This was a case of identify theft in order to profit from the good name of Voyager and crew.

Question:
What are the names of the two main characters in Naomi Wildman's
holodeck simulation?
Narrative: n

Question: In this episode, what did the inhabitants of the planet call Voyager?
Narrative:
Voyager becomes locked in orbit of a planet on which times passes much faster than on Voyager. This causes tectonic issues on the planet that
threatens the planet. Eventually, the inhabitants reach a level of technology that allows them to free Voyager.

Question: Jason Alexander (known from Seinfeld) appeared in which episode?
Narrative:
Kurros was the spokesperson of the "Think Tank", a diverse group of alien scholars who traveled about the galaxy, offering to solve
 people's problems for a price.

Question:
Which of the following was a new feature for starships, unique to
Voyager at the time?
Narrative:
The nacelles were "raised" for warp speed, and "lowered" for sub-light speed. There is no specific information to describe why this was
necessary or desirable, but there is speculation that this lessened the impact of warp fields on inhabited planets.

Question:
If this series was picked up for a 5th season, what upgrade would
NX-01 Enterprise have received?
Narrative:
We'll never know for sure, because Enterprise was not renewed for a 5th season. But the hull was planned to be an "outer" hull that would
have made NX-01 more resemble NCC-1701.

Question: What species built a weapon that was created to destroy Earth?
Narrative:
The Xindi, falsely believing that humans would destroy their homeworld if they did not strike first, created a weapon designed to destroy Earth.
Fortunately, the lie was seen through and the Xindi did not destroy Earth.

Question: What crewman was "Sim" a clone of?
Narrative: Sim was created when Dr. Phlox used a Lyssarian Desert Larvae which has the unique ability to rapidly grow into a genetic duplicate of a human.

Question:
This episode features a character portraying a Ferengi that was a 
regular in a previous series. Which character?
Narrative: Ethan Phillips, who played Neelix on Star Trek: Voyager, portrayed a Ferengi named Ulis.

Question:
In this episode, T'Pol tells Captain Archer and Trip Tucker a story of an
alternate Vulcan/Human first contact. When asked if the story was true,
what was T'Pol's reply?
Answer 3: You asked me to tell you a story.
Correct Answer: You asked me to tell you a story.
Narrative:
In the final scene of the episode, T'Pol opens an old handbag and retrieves a picture of T'Mir and her crewmates, and a piece of velcro, 
indicating that the story was indeed true.

Question:
In this episode, what group is suspected of bombing the Earth
embassy on Vulcan?
Narrative:
Admiral Maxwell Forrest is having a discussion with ambassador Soval in the Earth embassy on Vulcan when a bomb explodes, 
killing 43 people including Forrest.

Question:
In this episode, Dr. Emory Erickson arrives onboard Enterprise, 
supposedly to conduct tests for subquantum transportation. What is his
true mission?
Narrative:
The crew reluctantly follows Erickson's lead as he tries to re-materialize Quinn from a phantom-like state stemming from a transporter
 accident 15 years earlier.

Question: In this two part episode, who is revealed to be the emperor?
Narrative:
After gaining control of the Terran Empire's most powerful starship, the USS Defiant, Hoshi declares herself Empress, leveraging the
 advanced technology of the Defiant to seize power.

Question:
In this two part episode, which ship does the emperor acquire to solidfy
power?
Narrative: Once the USS Defiant is acquired, Hoshi Sato declares herself Empress.

Question: What type of dog did Captain Archer have onboard NX-01?
Narrative:
Captain Archer's dog was a Beagle named Porthos, a name from "The Three Musketeers" by Alexandre Dumas. In the novel, Porthos is
 one of the three  loyal musketeers serving the French king, alongside Athos and Aramis. The name reflects the loyalty and companionship
 that Archer values  in his canine friend.

Question: How many species of Xindi still exist in the Entperise NX-01's timeline?
Narrative: The Xindi were five distinct species: Primate, Insectoid, Reptilian, Aquatic and Arboreal. A sixth species, Avian, are extinct.

Question:
Daniels, a time traveler prominent in the Temporal Cold War was from
which century?
Narrative:
Daniels was an operative from the 31st century and a major player in the Temporal Cold War. Daniels had frequent interactions with
 the crew of Enterprise NX-01 in the 2150s and often assisted them in preventing temporal incursions by various factions in the Cold War.

Question:
William Shatner thought that this film was a flop after seeing it on the
big screen for the first time. What was his reply when asked about it
15 years later?
Answer 1: I stand by my original statement
Answer 4: I still think it was crap
Narrative:
Shatner, who saw the completed film for the first time at the world premiere, was struck by the overall sluggishness of this film, and was convinced
 that the Star Trek franchise died there and then. He opined, "Well, that's it. We gave it our best shot, it wasn't good, and it will never happen again.

Question:
Which actor stated that they didn't like the uniforms worn in this film
 because they were unisex and too drab?
Narrative: Nichols noted in her autobiography that she was one of the actresses most opposed to the new uniforms added for this film.

Question:
Which actor agreed to appear in this film only after the studio agreed to
a settlement for using his likeness in advertising without permission?
Narrative:
Henry Fonda told Nimoy that he hoped he (Nimoy) would receive a lot of money for all those ads. Nimoy was completely unaware that his
 likeness as Spock was being used in Heineken beer advertisements, including billboards and a now famous commercial.

Question:
This film's theme was so liked by Gene Roddenberry, that it was used 
again in which future productions?
Answer 1:
The Next Generation and The
Final Frontier
Answer 2:
Voyager and The Wrath of
Khan
Answer 3:
Deep Space Nine and The Voyage
Home
Correct Answer:
The Next Generation and The
Final Frontier
Narrative:
Roddenberry so loved the main theme from the score that he reused this for Star Trek: The Next Generation (1987). This was also reused in
 Star Trek V: The Final Frontier (1989), after not being used in the second, third and fourth films.

Question: Which main cast member's twin sons were cast as extras in this film?
Narrative: Doohan's twin sons, Montgomery Doohan and Christopher Doohan, appear as extras in this film.

Question:
The uniforms worn in this film were re-used in which future film or
television series?
Narrative:
The uniforms that appear in this film never again appear in any other Star Trek episode or movie. What appears to be a buckle on the uniform
 was intended to be a device that relays medical readings to the medical bay computer.

Question:
Which famous science fiction author provided technical consultation for
this film?
Narrative:
This film also received technical consultation from NASA, the Jet Propulsion Laboratory at California Institute of Technology, and the
 Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

Question: One of the several derogatory nicknames for this film included what?
Narrative: Others derogatory names included The Motion Sickness Picture and The Slow Motion Picture.

Question: Where (on Earth) were the scenes of Vulcan filmed?
Narrative:
Yellowstone was selected for Vulcan after filming in Turkish ruins proved to be too expensive. Securing permission for filming the scenes was difficult in the
 middle of the summer tourist season, but the Parks Department acquiesced so long as the crew remained on the boardwalks to prevent damage to geological formations.

Question:
The long-range shuttle carrying Spock has Vulcan lettering on the top
 of the side of the craft, and under this reads...what?
Narrative: Surak was the founder of Vulcan logic and the idea of suppression of emotions.

Question:
After reluctantly being convinced to appear in the first film, Leonard Nimoy
 initially had no interest in a second. Harve Bennett finally convinced
 Nimoy to sign onto the film.What did he offer Nimoy?
Narrative: Presumably to ensure that Nimoy would never be cast again in the franchise. I think we all know how that went.

Question: Which of the following items were displayed in Kirk's ready room?
Narrative: Some of the other items in the ready room included a sextant, a ship's wheel and antique books.

Question:
Which of the Reliant's crew was a recurring member of the Enterprise
 crew on The Original Series
Narrative: Chekov is a regular crew member, whereas Kyle was a recurring crew member.

Question:
Other than Leonard Nimoy, what actor initially declined to return for this
film?
Narrative: Takei was subsequently convinced to return to reprise his role as Sulu after William Shatner asked him to reconsider.

Question:
The scenic view of San Francisco through Kirk's apartment window is a
 painting, originally created for which film?
Narrative:
In front of the backdrop were placed a couple of models of futuristic skyscrapers, with working lights and elevators. Thus, assuming that Kirk's apartment is in the same place as
 the tower in "The Towering Inferno", then his address is 655 Market Street, San Francisco, California, on the 135th floor.

Question: In this film, how was USS Reliant differentiated from the USS Enterprise?
Answer 2:
The nacelles were below the
fuselage
Correct Answer:
The nacelles were below the
fuselage
Narrative:
As the fundamental components of both ships are the same (saucer, nacelles, etc.), this was seen as being an effective way to visually differentiate the two vessels, particularly
 during action sequences when both ships are in the same scene.

Question: What was used to make the Ceti Eels used by Khan appear "slimy"?
Narrative:
The baby Ceti eels were pulled along the actors' cheeks using a piece of string. They were made out of a stretchy rubber, allowing them to seem to crawl along, and covered with
 raspberry jelly to give them a slimy appearance.

Question:
Marla McGivers from the TOS episode Space Seed did not appear in this
film. The reason given in the film was that she died while in exile.
What killed her?
Narrative: The character of Marla McGivers from Space Seed (1967) was originally intended to reappear in this film, with Madlyn Rhue reprising her role.

Question:
The Genesis sequence called for a long and massive explosion. Where
in San Francisco was this filmed?
Narrative:
ILM rented the Cow Palace in San Francisco for the effect. They covered the ceiling with a black cloth and placed the camera on the floor looking up at it. The explosion
 would occur directly above the camera so the fall-out would appear to rush directly towards the point of view.

Question: What was unusual about Saavik's name?
Narrative: Previously, only male Vulcans had names that began with "S" (Spock, Sarek, Surak) while female Vulcans had name that began with "T" (T'Pau, T'Pring).

Question:
Leonard Nimoy directed this film and his first choice to play Kruge was
not Christopher Lloyd. Who was?
Narrative: Nimoy finally cast Lloyd because he came off more operatic and physically intimidating.

Question:
When the crew is standing on the bluff supposedly watching the flaming
Enterprise hulk, they were in fact watching...what?
Narrative: Yep. That's right. They were in fact watching a tennis ball mounted on an overhead boom microphone.

Question: How many different actors portrayed Spock in this film?
Narrative: This includes Spock as an adult and five stages of growth after being found on the Genesis planet.

Question:
When beaming down in the transporter room, what sign can be seen
in the back?
Narrative:
Although Gene Roddenberry had this sign removed in another area of the ship, it remained in the transporter room. Roddenberry thought that the use of tobacco
would not a a thing of the future.

Question:
This film's broadcast network premiere came slightly earlier than first 
planned. ABC decided to broadcast the film instead of what?
Narrative: ABC decided to broadcast the film instead of Monday Night Football during the first week of the 1987 NFL players strike.
